flights.Key_Evidence: • Meets pure schedule-variance threshold for Early Arrival; no higher-priority root cause found. | • Controller anticipates possible gate coordination because aircraft arrived far ahead of schedule; consistent with gate not yet available due to very early arrival, not because of a late-running departure. | • Shows aircraft checking in with ramp shortly after landing—no indication of mechanical, FAA gate holds, late tow, or other specific root causes.

flights.Key_Evidence: • Immediately after landing the crew is told to head toward gate F5 but then instructed to HOLD because the gate is not available – first indication that something is blocking F5. | • Identifies United 643 as the aircraft occupying / awaiting the same gate area; United 643 is an arrival, not a departure, so any removal must be by tow rather than push-back. | • Confirms United 643 is being moved UNDER TOW away from the gate area, establishing that the blocking aircraft required a tow-off and that tow did not begin until more than 30 minutes after SKW5617 landed, causing the prolonged taxi-in delay.

Evidence_Details.message: Skyway 3617, Tango, go to Foxtrot 5 ... contact the gate for 1922, hold you back there.

Evidence_Details.message: United 643 at Delta, hold short of runway 28L, we'll just hold you there for a few minutes until your gate opens up.
Evidence_Details.relevance: Identifies United 643 as the aircraft occupying / awaiting the same gate area; United 643 is an arrival, not a departure, so any removal must be by tow rather than push-back.

Evidence_Details.message: United 643, approaching spot 9, under tow … Bravo Echo Alpha to the ramp, United 643.
Evidence_Details.relevance: Confirms United 643 is being moved UNDER TOW away from the gate area, establishing that the blocking aircraft required a tow-off and that tow did not begin until more than 30 minutes after SKW5617 landed, causing the prolonged taxi-in delay.

flights.Key_Evidence: • Meets ≥15-minute early-arrival threshold; establishes schedule-driven possibility before any other cause | • Immediately after landing the aircraft is told to hold, indicating gate not ready even though physically unoccupied – a typical early-arrival hold | • Controller gives an approximate waiting time, consistent with holding because flight arrived well ahead of planned gate-time, not because of any specific mechanical or tow issue | • After ~38 minutes of post-landing taxi/holds the aircraft finally approaches the gate area, confirming extended taxi-in caused by earlier holds | • No late-departure, tow, or mechanical blockage – eliminates higher-priority operational causes, leaving early arrival as primary root cause

flights.Key_Evidence: • Controller tells SKW4661 its gate F8 will not be free until 09:25, showing the aircraft arrived well before the gate was scheduled to become available. | • Confirms the planned gate-open time and that no unexpected operational problem (e.g., mechanical, tow, crew) is keeping the gate occupied— it is simply not scheduled to free until 09:25. | • Gate-history data verifies the previous aircraft was NOT late; thus the delay is driven solely by SKW4661’s 49-minute-early arrival, satisfying the pure ‘Early Arrival’ criteria.

flights.Key_Evidence: • Indicates DAL1091 had been given an initial taxi-in route toward the Bravo pier, confirming it was ready to proceed toward the gate area. | • Controller is already reallocating parking for another aircraft inside the same Bravo alley, signalling that the alley is saturated with traffic and space is tight. | • Tower tells an aircraft it must wait until its own company aircraft moves, indicating aircraft in the alley are blocking each other and producing a hold. | • Ground frequency confirms they will hold position until another aircraft clears, demonstrating a congestion-driven delay inside the alley leading to the B-gates. | • Shows the gate itself was available well before DAL1091 landed, eliminating gate occupancy as the cause and supporting congestion in the taxi lanes/alley as the root delay driver.

Evidence_Details.message: Delta 1091, ramp enters, spot 1, Mike 5 to Bravo 5.
Evidence_Details.relevance: Indicates DAL1091 had been given an initial taxi-in route toward the Bravo pier, confirming it was ready to proceed toward the gate area.

Evidence_Details.message: 805, if you don't have room there, you can use Bravo 2.
Evidence_Details.relevance: Controller is already reallocating parking for another aircraft inside the same Bravo alley, signalling that the alley is saturated with traffic and space is tight.

Evidence_Details.message: …yeah, just, uh, you can use, yeah, we'll, we'll stick with this hammer out once you, once your company moves.
Evidence_Details.relevance: Tower tells an aircraft it must wait until its own company aircraft moves, indicating aircraft in the alley are blocking each other and producing a hold.

Evidence_Details.message: Nah, we're gonna wait. Okay, uh, yeah, just, uh, can you, yeah, we'll, we'll switch to ground once you, once the company moves.
Evidence_Details.relevance: Ground frequency confirms they will hold position until another aircraft clears, demonstrating a congestion-driven delay inside the alley leading to the B-gates.

Evidence_Details.message: Gate B5 was vacant since 22:58, previous flight SJX11 pushed early.
Evidence_Details.relevance: Shows the gate itself was available well before DAL1091 landed, eliminating gate occupancy as the cause and supporting congestion in the taxi lanes/alley as the root delay driver.
